variant.question:
An aircraft is in cruising flight at FL140 at TAS 200 kts
The pilot intends to descend at 500 ft/min to arrive overhead the MAN VOR at 2 000 ft (QNH 1030 hPa)
The TAS remains constant in the descent, wind is negligible, temperature standard
At which distance from MAN should the pilot commence the descent?

You are descending from FL280 at a constant CAS of 250 kt in ISA conditions. At the beginning of the descent, you check your instruments and read a TAS of 381 kt and a Mach number of 0.64. At some time, during the descent, you check the instruments again. Which value of TAS and Mach number would you expect to read?

At some time, during the descent, you check the instruments again. Which value of TAS and Mach number would you expect to read?

At the beginning of the descent, the pilot, after checking the instruments, reads a CAS of 274 kt and a TAS of 416 kt. At some point during the descent, when he/she re-checks the instruments, which value of TAS and CAS would he/she expect to read?

variant.question: In which of the following conditions is there the most risk of CFIT?

options.text: Overcast cloud layer with a low ceiling and the underlying ground being completely covered by snow.
Night flight around largely populated cities.
During a flight in a mountainous area with strong wind conditions.
High headwind and turbulence causing rapid changes in vertical speed indications.

variant.question: The automatic flight control system (AFCS) in an aircraft is coupled to the guidance outputs of an inertial navigation system (INS).
